speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these feeding difficulties you're experiencing? Is it a problem with swallowing, or do you just not seem to want to eat?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama's trying to feed me, but I don't wanna... it hurts when she touches my tummy."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's helpful to know. Can you show me exactly where it hurts when your mom tries to feed you?

speaker: Patient
text: "Ow, ow, ow! Right here! *points to abdomen*"

speaker: Doctor
text: I see. So the pain is localized to the abdomen. Can you tell me, does the pain happen only when your mom tries to feed you, or does it happen at other times as well?

speaker: Patient
text: "It hurts sometimes when Mama picks me up or when I'm lying down. It feels like... like something is squeezing me."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly where it feels like something is squeezing you?

speaker: Patient
text: "Right here... *points to abdomen again*... it feels like my tummy is getting bigger and tighter. Sometimes it makes me feel like I need to cry."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the pain and feeling of tightness in your abdomen has been going on for a while, or did it start suddenly?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started a few days ago... I don't remember when exactly, but Mama said I was crying a lot and she was worried. Before that, I was eating and playing just fine."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you have had any changes in your bowel movements or urination habits recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so... Mama says I'm still going potty like usual. But sometimes I feel like I need to go, but nothing comes out. And my tummy still feels yucky."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're having some issues with constipation and possibly urinary retention. Can you tell me if you've had any vomiting or diarrhea recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, no vomiting or diarrhea. Just a lot of crying and discomfort. And my tummy still feels tight and sore."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly how your tummy feels when it's tight and sore? Does it feel hard or soft to the touch?

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels... hard. Like a big, hard ball in my tummy. When Mama touches it, it hurts even more."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's very helpful. Can you tell me if your mom has noticed any changes in your behavior or appetite recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama says I've been less interested in playing and looking at toys. I just want to cry and be held. And I don't seem to want to eat as much as I used to."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've had any fever or chills recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, no fever or chills. Just this yucky feeling in my tummy and a lot of crying."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the pain and discomfort in your tummy have been constant or do they come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It comes and goes... sometimes it's really bad and I cry a lot, and sometimes it's a little better and I can calm down. But it never really goes away completely."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see. So the pain and discomfort in your tummy are intermittent, but never completely go away. That's helpful to know. Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your skin or eyes recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "My skin feels... hot. And my eyes are all red and puffy from crying. Mama says I look a little yellow, but I don't know what that means."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what you mean by your skin feeling hot? Is it just in certain areas or all over your body?

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels hot... all over, I think. Especially on my tummy and chest. Mama says it's because I'm getting a little more hair and that's why I feel warm."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me where your skin feels hot on your tummy and chest?

speaker: Patient
text: "Right here... *points to abdomen and chest*. It feels like my skin is on fire. Sometimes it makes me want to cry even more."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the hot feeling on your skin is related to the pain and discomfort in your tummy?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, it feels like it's all connected. When my tummy hurts, my skin feels hot and it makes me want to cry even more."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'm concerned about the possibility of a bowel obstruction. Can you tell me if you've had any difficulty passing gas or if you've noticed any changes in the sound of your bowel movements?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama says I don't pass gas as much as I used to. And when I do, it doesn't smell like it usually does. It's all... different. And sometimes I make a weird noise when I go potty. It sounds like... like something is stuck."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this weird noise you make when you go potty? Is it a loud noise or a soft one?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's a... a weird, gurgly noise. Like when Mama makes soup on the stove and it's all bubbly. But it's coming from me, and it makes me feel embarrassed and scared."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the gurgly noise you hear when you go potty is constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It comes and goes... sometimes it's really loud and I can hear it clearly, and sometimes it's softer and I'm not sure if anyone else can hear it. But it always makes me feel a little scared and worried."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the gurgly noise you hear when you go potty is related to the pain and discomfort in your tummy?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, it's all connected. When my tummy hurts, the noise gets louder and it makes me feel even more scared and worried. Mama says it sounds like my tummy is making a bunch of bubbles, but I don't like it. It makes me feel like something is stuck in there and it can't come out."

speaker: Doctor
text: I think I have a good idea of what might be going on. One more question to confirm: Have you had any vomiting or regurgitation of food or formula recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama says I've been bringing up a little bit of milk sometimes after feeding. It's not much, but it's enough to make her worried. And sometimes I make a little burp, but it doesn't feel like a normal burp. It feels like... like something is trying to come up, but it's not coming out."
